text:
Calls for NT to wipe historical gay sex convictions Posted Wed 22 Feb 2017, 5:26pm Updated Thu 23 Feb 2017, 4:10pm 
By Alice Matthews Calls for NT to wipe historical gay sex convictions 
Human rights lawyers have urged the Northern Territory Government to wipe the historical criminal records of those convicted of having consensual gay sex, in line with every other Australian state and territory. 
The NT is the only jurisdiction in the country not to commit to reform, after the two major parties in Western Australia threw their support behind quashing these convictions, ahead of the state's March election. 
"Any process to quash such convictions may be a complex one, involving constitutional issues, and is likely to involve the Commonwealth as the Northern Territory didn't gain self-government until 1978. " 
Consensual adult male homosexuality activity was decriminalised in the NT in 1983. 
In June 2016, the Castan Centre for Human Rights Law at Monash University wrote to the Northern Territory questioning its lack of action. 
More than six months later, the University's Professor Paula Gerber said she still hasn't had a reply. 
She sent a follow up letter today. 
"It is imperative that the NT join the other jurisdictions to prevent any further harm caused by shame, stigmatisation and undue discrimination," the letter reads. 
These are convictions that should never have recorded in the first place and it's time the law should recognise that fact." 
Professor Gerber said neglecting to clear the record denied the the LGBTQI community a powerful healing step. 
"And it sends a message to young people that it's still not OK to have a sexual orientation other than heterosexual," she said. 
"This is just a simple bit of housekeeping, a bit of tidying up that can be dealt with efficiently and effectively, yet the impact it has on these people's lives is immeasurable." 'Increasing reliance on criminal record checks' 
She said one man in New South Wales stayed in the same job for 22 years because he thought if he left, he would be subjected to a criminal records check in a new job. 
"He was 17 years old [when he was convicted], parked in a car with his boyfriend... they'd gone to a well-known make out spot and been arrested...he lived with this and it had an impact on his life every day," she said. 
The New South Wales Government now has a system in place for such convictions to be expunged. 
In 2016, the Premier apologised to those who were treated as criminals for being gay. 
Professor Gerber said the Territory's failure to introduce legislation wasn't exactly intentional, but more of an oversight. 
"But now I think we are seeing increasing reliance on criminal record checks; there's very little you can do these days without having to provide a criminal record check," she said. 
"So it is actually becoming perhaps a bigger problem than it was a decade ago when criminal record checks weren't as prevalent as they are now," she said. 
LGBTQI activist and Sydney trans woman Danika Hardiman, 24, said it was shocking to discover there are people out there whose sexuality was criminalised. 
"It's another battle we have to face against homophobia..even if it only affects a small minority it's important and symbolic," she said. 
"Even if you're not going to be personally affected, what does it say to Australian society at large that people have been convicted as sex offenders for engaging in homosexual sex?" Reform in the NT more complex 
Hack understands more than 30 Supreme Court Records exist for offences pertaining to homosexuality in the NT up until 1962. 
The first gay, Indigenous MLA in the NT, 29-year-old Chansey Paech, said wiping the convictions in the Territory is more complex than other jurisdictions. 
The NT up until 1978 was under the control of the Federal Government. 
"A lot of those charges are pre-1978, so it's working through how we deal with that because there's a potential we need to deal with federal bodies to look at overturning those particular cases," he said. 
He told Hack he will lobby the NT government to expunge convictions for consensual gay sex. 
"Changing this sends a message to our young people that people had to fight for those in our community now to have basic rights, and this is a demonstration of how people were treated and how their rights were not seen as equal," he said. 
"It's something we need to move on...it's a conversation I'm intending to have very soon with our Attorney General." 
He said it was about righting wrongs. 
"We talk about gay marriage and we talk about same sex adoption and we advocate and we lobby, I think that making sure these charges are wiped is just as important because we need to fix and reconcile some things of our past," he said. 
Hack has contacted the Attorney General's office for comment. 
Update: Since publication, the NT Government has said it is now seeking advice on expunging gay sex convictions. 
A spokesperson said "every Territorian has a right to dignity and respect." Facebook Comments
